reviewText: First off, let me say that I dont have a problem with the dinosaurs. Why?  Because I saw this story in High School (20 years ago +) and I thought they were dreadful, but acceptable considering I understood the limitations of the production. Over time the the dinosaurs became exgerated in my head. I thought of them as being much worse than they truly are. So. that stuff aside. Its a solid story.  I wish I could say that the color enhanced episode one is a major disappointment. Color restoration had been impressive in the past on stories such as Terror of the Autons. For this version BBC only had partial color information and added the blue with a computer. So the blues look great and the rest looks pretty rough, especially browns and flesh tones. I must say that I am puzzled as to why they couldnt use a computer colorization technique to bring the entire episode up to the standards of the rest of the show. Especially when one considers they had the rest of the serial for reference it is a puzzle. Is colorization that expensive?  Some of the color by computer work done in the past ten years has been quite impressive if not perfect. But superior to what BBC has provided.  Note to anyone making a movie with puppet monsters/dinosaurs/spaceships:  Try filming things backward and then reversing it in editing. It effectively creates the illusion that the object is propelling itself.
summary: Wondrful fun but DVD puzzles at times.

reviewText: I hate it when the BBC updates the special effects in an original Doctor Who story with state-of-the-art digital effects, as they did recently with "Day of the Daleks," for example. The original material should be allowed to stand (or topple over) on its own, without the benefit of CGI wizardry. Besides, primitive special effects are part of the charm of this landmark science-fiction series. In the case of "Invasion of the Dinosaurs," however, I would have loved it if the BBC had updated the story with CGI, but they didn't.The dinosaur effects in "Invasion" are so bad they defy description and seriously detract from an already shaky story. Your 10-year-old nephew could have done better with a home video camera and his plastic dinosaur collection (and, for all I know, somebody's nephew at the BBC did provide the dinosaur effects for this story).Meanwhile, the premise for "Invasion" is kind of preposterous, even for Doctor Who: The Doctor and Sarah return from their adventures in "The Time Warrior" to a deserted central London that's swarming with looters. Dinosaurs are mysteriously appearing and disappearing through what the Doctor terms "time eddies"--localized time distortions created by someone tinkering with time. The Doctor and Sarah deduce the parties responsible must be drawing on a nuclear power source hidden somewhere within the city. Determined to find this power source, Sarah is captured and wakes up aboard what she's told is a spaceship of colonists in suspended animation on course to an Earth-like planet unspoiled by pollution. Meanwhile, Capt. Mike Yates of UNIT is in cahoots with the wacko environmentalists behind the time distortions--a highly improbable and unconvincing betrayal.If you read the onscreen commentary and view some of the Special Features on the second, companion disc, you'll begin to see where this story went wrong. Writer Malcolm Hulke had written one of his typically intelligent scripts involving aliens and topical political concerns (in this case, the environment). Producer Barry Letts and script editor Terrance Dicks, however, decided to substitute dinosaurs for aliens but were too distracted by their work on another series, Moonbase 3, to notice they had neither the budget nor the technical expertise to make the dinosaurs work.In mitigation, I must mention that the Special Features disc includes a fun, 14-minute interview with the late Elisabeth Sladen, "The Doctor Who Stories: Sarah Jane Smith, Part 1." Ms. Sladen passed away in 2011 after a protracted battle with cancer. She will be missed.

reviewText: I recently watched this episode and the story itself is gripping, the acting is superb, the tension is palpable and essentially this is the very best 3rd Doctor/Sarah Jane Smith story produced and one of all time fav 3rd Doctor stories and I'll tell you why:Personally it's my favorite with Pertwee and Sladen as I thought the Time Warrior was a bit simple for DW and although I did love the intricacies and end episodes of Planet of the Spiders. I simply do not care for Curse of Peladon much at all.Death to the Daleks is fine in concept and I do very much like the puzzles that the Doctor has to get through towards the end which remind me heavily of The Five Doctors. Cross Death to the Daleks with The Three Doctors and basically you have The Five Doctors before it ever happened!Overall I guess what I am reviewing here is the total era of Sarah Jane and the 3rd Doctor, what makes Dinosaurs so great is that Elizabeth Sladen really gets the chance to shine here whereas she is for the most part pushed aside in the other stories with her and Pertwee together.For me the only reason the Time Warrior is of note is that it is Sarah Jane's introduction to the series and it's always interesting to have a mostly historical setting for The Doctor as after William Hartnell they became so few and far between.I hadn't seen Dinosaurs in a very long time but when I watched this again recently I was very surprised how much Ioved it and the story really gripped me, I think it comes in a close second overall for me in the Pertwee era.The only thing that tops it is The Mind of Evil which I think is the 3rd Doctor's best story and both the story, direction, acting, not least of all the Brigadier, UNIT as a whole, The Doctor and The Master really shine there. The Same with Invasion of the Dinosaurs only instead of Roger Delgado we are given the gift that is Elizabeth Sladen as a core actor in the story, Sarah Jane for me outstrips any companion from any era of the 50 year history of the show.I think people love Elizabeth and Sarah Jane because of her wholesomeness and fortitude, the endearingness of the actress and her easygoingness. Of course she shines mostly with Baker, not only in those terrified damsel in distress scenes but in the funny, sometimes sad little personal scenes which is what will always make Sarah Jane Smith the BEST companion/assistant/friend The Doctor ever has had or ever will have.A lot of people who dismiss Doctor Who when compared to other Sci-fi aren't really looking at it, from the start when the very first companion left the show Carol Anne Ford in Invasion of the Daleks, a departing of a major companion has always been a bittersweet moment. DW has always been fun, poignant and ultimately human in its rendition of this inhuman character. What grounds The Doctor is us and the most human and most relatable of all the companions was Sarah Jane.Because we would all love to think that in those situations travelling with the Doctor we would all be as sometimes brave, as sometimes genuinely and sincerely terrified, as curious and just as independent and defiant to The Doctor himself as Sarah was.The fact that Sarah and The Doctor seem to have a very genuine fondness for each other and an equal footing intellectually and emotionally only goes to compound this. For me always watching Sarah and the 4th Doctor is like watching to colleagues who have grown to love one another but never want to ruin the friendship by taking the relationship a step further... On a superficial level many may not see it, they simply see Sarah as the companion The Doctor has to save in a sea of overwrought with so many women over the decades that we have all come to know. But Sarah is special because truly she was the Doctor's only equal in the TARDIS even above Romana who plainly did what she was bade. But Sarah had a mind and brilliance all her own, and being the only companion from the classic series (besides K-9) to crossover to the new she has the distinction of being the greatest companion and friend to The Doctor of all time because as so many often say like a fine wine a beautiful and gracious woman only becomes more sweet and more wonderful with time so does our Sarah Jane.Invasion of the Dinosaurs may not be the best DW story of all time, nor in my opinion is it even the best 3rd Doctor story but it has the unique and wonderful distinction of being one of the few Sarah Jane Smith stories out of so many episodes of this great long running series so cherish it!And with all that being said, yes I agree the dinos are pretty bad but some people still complain about how the original King Kong looks too. What they are not understanding that in that time and with the budget that the show had it was the best they could muster. So that aside, this is a really great story and a really great outing for Sarah Jane Smith, the Brigadier and the 3rd Doctor!On one last note since many of the DW DVD's do sport redone special effects like The Ark In Space and The Dalek Invasion of Earth and The Five Doctors you would think that Invasion of the Dinosaurs would warrant the same treatment to be able to choose between the original effects and something new.Wouldn't it be wonderful if us, the fans were treated to a Special Edition of Invasion of the Dinosaurs with the old dino effects replaced by new ones by those great people who do the Primeval series in the UK?Now that would just make this story perfect and raise it up to I believe the very best Pertwee and give it the respect it deserves because I'm betting that this is a very overlooked story merely because of the reputation the effects have.And that is very unfair because it's an intriguing political story as well as one of the very few Who episodes that can complete with the original Star Trek on the moralistic point that they drive home about how people are not taking care of the environment which is at the very heart of the story.
summary: The BEST Elizabeth Sladen/Jon Pertwee story hands down!!!

reviewText: The 5-Star rating is for the quality and value of the DVD.  Superb job as is typical of the Doctor Who Restoration Team in their production of Classic Era Doctor Who DVD's.INVASION OF THE DINOSAURSStory # 71Season 11's Second StoryThird Doctor, Jon Perwee Era, final season 1973-74Second Classic Sarah Jane Smith storyOVERALL STORY RATING 8/10INVASION OF THE DINOSAURS is a 10/10 story pulled down to 8/10 solely due to poor dinosaur special effects.  If the viewer is willing to put forth a tiny bit of effort and engage their imagination when the dinosaurs are onscreen, the reward will be a truly superb story well worth the watching.  It is truly sad that such an excellent story is pulled so low by a single problem.  Were it not for the poor dinosaur special effects, INVASION OF THE DINOSAURS would likely rate among the finest WHO stories of all time, possibly even in the top 25.Essential for SARAH JANE ADVENTURES fans, and highly recommended for Whovians, both veteran and novice .STORY & SCRIPT 10/10Excellent Malcolm Hulke script. Many twists, turns and surprises for the viewer. Great dialog, impressive and creative story idea, believable and intriguing idealists as not-evil-just-misguided-villians.  All elements combined make for an impressive, intelligent well-above-average-WHO story that will engage the viewer mentally and emotionally.ACTING 10/10Superb performances across the board for main cast, UNIT and guest cast.  Jon Pertwee's "Third Doctor" is one of the best and most unique in WHO history, and he and Elisabeth Sladen have an entertaining, very watchable closeness and rapport making the Pertwee/Sladen companionship one of WHO's best-ever pairings. INVASION OF THE DINOSAURS looks much like an early test run for SARAH JANE ADVENTURES, as Elisabeth Sladen again lights up the screen in only her second story. Her portrayal of the serious-but-warm, girl-next-door, "Sarah Jane" pulls the viewer effortlessly into the story with her, and is a strong, capable, intelligent companion, whose actions move much of the story.  The UNIT team regulars are very impressive as detailed below.  The large guest cast is superb across the board with every performance engaging, believable and spotlessly done. One of the few WHO stories that can genuinely be rated "flawless" in all across-the-board performances.  Veteran Whovians will recognize the incredible Peter Miles(Professor Whitaker) and excellent John Bennett (General Finch) from superb performances each will give in two WHO masterpiece stories to come in Seasons 12 and 14.PRODUCTION QUALITY 10/10The sets are so well built, effectively filmed and believable overall, that even a minor wobble here-and-there, does not detract from the viewer's overall belief in the scenes and story.  Paddy Russell's imaginative direction is every bit as impressive in overlooked, underrated INVASION OF THE DINOSAURS as it is in the highly respected and recognized PYRAMIDS OF MARS, and HORROR OF FANG ROCK.SPECIAL EFFECTS 2/10The dinosaurs are so poorly realized onscreen that the score is pulled down to a "2/10" "far below average" even though other special effects are very well done. Minus the poorly realized dinosaur special effects, this story has superb producton values. Paddy Russell's filming of deserted London is particularly spooky, disturbing and chilling, giving the viewer a strong sense that something is terribly wrong.  The "Time Eddy" presentation onscreen is very well done, even by today's standards, a surprisingly good achievement considering the limitations of mid-1970's CSO technology.STORY IMPORTANCE 9/10One of the best stories for the UNIT Team.  The Brigadier, Yates, and Benton each get their chance to shine, and they and the stunt UNIT regulars are in great form, acting and looking like a genuine military organization, and pull off a few major surprises for the viewer, which helps bump this story up considerably from a normal "5/10" average "Importance" rating. It is definitely one of the finest and most ambitious Pertwee-era stories and that is saying a lot, as there are some genuinely GREAT stories during Jon Pertwee's run as the Third Doctor, Season 7-through-11.DVD EXTRAS 9/10Excellent across the board except as noted in the following remarks.  The excellent PEOPLE, POWER AND PUPPETRY documentary truly gets to the heart of what makes INVASION OF THE DINOSAURS such a superb story.  The on-screen text information by David Brunt is also excellent. However, the commentary is a bit disappointing for once. The commentary is excellent in Parts 2, 3 & 6, but gets off-topic in Parts 1,4 & 5, where director Paddy Russell and moderator Toby Hadoke are the only participants and Russell's career outside of WHO is discussed as much or more than INVASION OF THE DINOSAURS. It is very disappointing that the commentary isn't mostly as it is in Parts 2, 3 & 6, actually concerning the making of the story itself, and less about Paddy Russell's career in-and-outside WHO. I would have much preferred to listen to more observations and memories from Richard Franklin, Peter Miles, Terence Wilton and Terrance Dicks.DOCTOR WHO STORIES: ELISABETH SLADEN PART 1 is a 14 minute interview from 2003 with Elisabeth Sladen, that is so delightful, that the poignancy hits extra hard on the realization that with her passing on April 19, 2011, the WHO world lost a genuine, irreplacable, treasure. Keep it running past the credits for a cute little surprise.These wonderful DVD extras are what make Classic WHO DVD's such special treats, so DO NOT overlook them as you will be losing a tremendous portion of the enormous value of a Classic WHO DVD!COMMENTARY ParticipantsToby Hadoke(Moderator) & Paddy Russell(Director) in Parts 1,4 & 5.Parts 2,3 & 6 has varied participation with Toby Hadoke(Moderator), by Richard Franklin, Peter Miles, Terence Wilton(Actors), and Terrance Dicks(Script Editor); [special 10-minute solo commentary by John Levene(Actor, Sgt Benton) available on Part 5].PEOPLE, POWER AND PUPPETRY ParticipantsMatthew Sweet(Presenter); John Pertwee-1993 Interview, Terence Wilton, Peter Miles(Actors); Barry Letts(Producer); Paddy Russell(Director); Terrance Dicks(Script Editor); Richard Morris(Designer).
summary: Classic Doctor Who: INVASION OF THE DINOSAURS

reviewText: In the Jon Pertwee era epsidoe entitled "Invasion of the Dinosuars" The Doctor and Sarah have returned from there adventure in the 12th century only to discover London deserted.  No people, no sounds not even birds chirping the Doctor is curious and so is Sarah. They discover a group of theives stealing from the stores and taking everything they can.  Military personel have caught up to both the Doctor and Sarah and the thieves and arrested them.  But not before encountering a dinosuar attack and the Doctor seems to understand what is going on.Meanwhile Brigader Letbridge-Sewart of U.N.I.T is having to deal with a regualr army general who demands that he place himself under his command and take control of the situation.  The Brigader reminds the general that U.N.I.T takes its orders from the United Nations and not the british goverment and for the time being the general is content to observe.The Doctor and Sarah after being cleared of any wrong doing by Captain Mike Yates and brought up to speed as to what is going and the Doctor thinks someone is disturbing the flow of time on Earth.  With the Brigader helping him he needs a dinosaur to track and hopefully figure where the time disturbances are comeing from. Sarah talks to one of the few officals still in London trying to maintain control of the military while they keep the threat under control.  What none of them know is a secert project called "Golden Age" is being acted upon by a select group of men all of which have placed into effect plans to end the world and resart it the way they intend.  Can the Doctor and Sarah stop the dinosaurs from destroying London?  Can they figure out what project "Golden Age" is really all about?  Can they trust those around them? Tune in to find out in "Invasion of the Dinosuars".
summary: The Doctor and Sarah Jane must try and find out why dinosuars are roaming through London before its too late.

reviewText: This is not billed as a Special Edition, but again it could be, there is enough info hereOk as usual I will skip the plot line its mentioned in the other reviews.I will mention this is the first time we see the Whomobile.Whomobile; A hovercraft-type vehicle that was also capable of flight, used by the Third Doctor in the serials Invasion of the Dinosaurs and Planet of the Spiders. The vehicle was also known as Alien, but was only ever referred to as "my car" by the Doctor in the television series. However, it is popularly referred to as the Whomobile. The vehicle was specially commissioned by and was the property of Jon Pertwee, and was not seen in the program again after he left it. It bore the license plate WV0 2M, and was registered as an invalid tricycle.2 Disks containing 6 Episodes and Special FeaturesDisk One:All six episodes and...special featuresSpecial Features:Disc One:Episode 1 Colour On/Off; You can watch this in both black and white and in colourAudio Options; CommentaryInfo Text On/Off; Still my favoriteComing Soon;Disc Two:People, Power And Puppetry;Deleted Scenes;Now and Then;Doctor Who Stories: Elisabeth Sladen Part 1Subtitles;John Levene CommentaryPhoto GalleryBilly Smart's CircusPDF Materials
summary: Another of these Special-- Non Special Editions.

reviewText: Being old school Doctor Who, the special effects are less than special. However, Dr. Who is a plot and character driven sort of thing and, as with most episodes, the actors and writers deliver something that is still fun to watch, even when the special effects of the episodes date back almost as far as the dinosaurs.The story features a limited time travel element and addresses the ethics of using extreme measures in the service of environmentalism. While Dr. Who often seems left-leaning, these episodes are clearly critical of the "by any means necessary" approach to environmentalism.As with many stories, there are captures and re-captures that tend to wear a bit thin-but when you have a lot of time to fill and a budget of six pence and a button, such is how things go.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is a very good story from Jon Pertwee's final year as the Doctor. It's an interesting story, has a good cast and is well acted, and it has one of the best episode cliffhangers ever on Doctor Who. A non-spoiler, brief overview: the Doctor and Sarah Jane Smith return to London to find it eerily empty and quiet. They discover that dinosaurs are appearing in central London, and the civilian population has been removed so that the army (and UNIT of course) can deal with the problem. After nasty encounters with looters, pterodactyls, and officious army personnel the Doctor and Sarah Jane are collected by the Brigadier and taken back to temporary UNIT HQ where the Doctor's knowledge is needed to deal with the dinosaur problem. Sarah Jane Smith, in intrepid investigative journalist mode goes and does research on her own to discover the power source being used to bring forth the dinosaurs. Meanwhile the Doctor tries to cobble together some scientific instruments that will allow him to find the physical location in London the dinosaurs where the dinosaurs are originating. Sarah Jane falls into some bad hands and finds herself on a spaceship going to colonize a distant planet, while the Doctor continues fighting the prehistoric beasties.The story has some wonderful things going for it, such as the eerie visuals of a deserted London. The performances from the regulars and the guest cast are quite strong. The story is interesting, multi-layered, and keeps moving at a fairly brisk pace for the entire 6 episodes.One of the items trumpeted about this release is that you have the option to watch a colorized version of episode 1. Well, OK, but are we really losing all that much information by watching it in black and white? For me the excitement was to finally see the first episode. My local PBS station only aired the 5 existing color episodes. Perhaps they thought we wouldn't be able to handle it if part of the story was in black and white, since they also never showed the black and white only episode of Planet of the Daleks. I really enjoyed watching episode 1 for the first time--from the atmospheric images of a deserted London, to the charming scenes where the Doctor and Sarah Jane are being arrested and processed by the military as looters, it's an excellent episode. Well, until the Tyrannosaurus-Rex shows up...OK, now we've gotten to the special effects, or as Terrance Dicks memorably described them once, the "wobbly dinosaurs". All right, let's start off with a disclaimer: you don't watch classic Doctor Who for the special effects. In fact if special effects are your main interest, do yourself a favor: eject this DVD and go find a Star Wars or a Jurassic Park movie to watch. Getting upset because the special effects in classic Doctor Who are not up to 21st century standards would be like getting upset with Jane Austen novels because there are no sex scenes.Having stated that, I must admit that the dinosaurs in this story are bad. Even by 1974 standards the dinosaurs are bad. In fact the wonderfully cheesy Sid and Marty Kroft series Land of the Lost, which was roughly contemporary with this story, has better dinosaur effects. HOWEVER, the dinosaurs are thankfully not on screen for much of the story. While not realistic, most of the dinosaurs didn't bother me too much. Unfortunately, the worst dinosaur puppet was the Tyrannosaurs Rex and it is used the most frequently.This is one of the few stories that I think it would have been nice to update the special effects, but they chose not to update them. I found this confusing, considering that even the producer and script editor found the special effects on this story quite lacking. Also, when considering the stories where they did update the special effects, many of which seemed fairly pointless (Destiny of the Daleks, did it really help to have better laser beams from the Daleks?...) it would have been nice to have a story updated that could honestly benefit from the update. Perhaps it was too difficult to recreate the dinosaur shots, or not cost effective.So what other extras are there on this 2-disc DVD set. There's the usual commentary option that shuffles through a large number of people involved in the story. It's o.k., but I don't think you really learn much that isn't covered in other places on the DVD. Toby Hadoke moderates a rotating group that includes Script Editor Terrance Dicks, actors Richard Franklin, Peter Miles, and Terrence Wilton, designer Richard Morris and Director Paddy Russell. It was recorded the day after Nicholas Courtney's funeral, and the commentary felt rather subdued. Director Paddy Russell was on her own with moderator Toby Hadoke on the two episodes she recorded commentary on. My favorite part was toward the end of episode 1 where the T-Rex makes his debut, and Paddy Russell enthusiastically says, "that looks good!!" and you can almost hear Toby Hadoke's jaw hitting the ground. There's actually a stunned silence then he asks her if she really thinks it looks good. However, except for the filming of the deserted London scenes it didn't appear that Paddy Russell had a lot of memories or much to say about this story. For her second episode of commentary Toby Hadoke wisely spent the time asking her about coming up as one of the first female directors at the BBC in the 60s, and about the early years of her career.The production notes option is quite informative, but again doesn't cover too much that isn't covered elsewhere, except for the changes to Malcolm Hulke's original story concept. There is also the option to watch 10 minutes of episode 5 with commentary from John Levene.The obligatory making of featurette is a little different on this DVD. The focus is on how unbelievable the story is. It was quite an interesting feature, but is the story of a scientist trying to take a specially selected group of humans back in time to "re-boot" humanity so to speak, really any less believable than say, green stuff coming up from the Earth's core turning people into greenish werewolf type creatures? I know they were trying to take the focus away from the dinosaur effects, but I don't think that was the best angle to take.Other extras include deleted scenes, and a photo gallery. I found the Now & Then for location filming sites well done, and more interesting than usual. Then there is the odd Billy Smart's Circus segment with an appearance of the Doctor and the Whomobile--very short, very awkward, and perhaps should have been an easter egg.Finally, the really special extra on this DVD set is Part one of an interview with Elisabeth Sladen. It appears that it was done around the time that she guested in the new Doctor Who episode School Reunion, but it was a fun look back on her time with the program. I look forward to seeing Part two of this interview on a future DVD.So to sum up: The story is a very good story. The special effects are lacking. The DVD extras are OK, but not stunning.
summary: Don't worry Brigadier the Brontosaurus is large, placid and stupid

reviewText: Now, all of us lets be mature and get past the puppet dinosaurs and see that "Invasion of the Dinosaurs" is a great addition to the series. The story is excellent. The acting, well, it was the '70s, give 'em a break. The chemistry between Sarah Jane and The Doctor is brilliant, especially during the first episode. The line between good guy and bad guy is tremendously well slurred and makes us wonder if The Doctor's doing the right thing. All in all, this is a great story and a wonderful tribute to the late Sladen, forever in our hearts.

reviewText: You'd think with Dinosaurs and conspirators running amuck, there would be a high body count for this show. Actually the only person who dies in this story is the looter from the first ten minutes of the first episode. Valuable life lesson from doctor who: If you steal stuff, you will die. If you plan to undo all of modern civilization because you feel like it, you just get sent to the past or you can resign from UNIT.

reviewText: Never has a Doctor Who story inspired me as much to sit down and write a review as this one did. If we were to believe so called fandom, then this story would be the so-called mistake, the one that should've been kept wiped, I've heard on some sites, not to mention the endless, ENDLESS question of "Can we have the Dinosaurs in CGI? Please? I'll be your best friend" that has been asked ever since the DVD range started.Firstly, the obvious. How much do the dinos appear in the story? Seriously? What I saw was more the Golden Age plan, and a much more intriguing and well-thought plot than others I could mention (Like The Android Invasion, which was released in the boxset with this story, UNIT Files). An avalanche of double-crossing between just about everyone left in London, mixed in with some genuine jaw-dropping moments.Like, say, the cliffhanger where Sarah wakes up to find she's not only in a spaceship, but "has apparently been asleep and travelling for 3 months." Huh? How's that for a revelation! How come no one talks about elements like this? I have to admit I've become a bit jaded when it comes to sci-fi/action/mystery, yet that was one of the few surprises that got me in recent times, seeing this story for the first time recently.I've seen that this story's average rating is 5 stars. I'm glad that this story has gotten such a positive re-appraisal. It deserves it. Well done to Jon Pertwee, Lis Sladen (R.I.P.) and all who created this masterpiece.
summary: Thank god for DVD and video.

reviewText: This six-parter contains the usual fine BBC presentation and atones for past carelessness in destroying original material (causing Episode 1 to exist in black-and-white only) by offering a good color recreation of Episode 1 as well. The commentary track and other special features are well-done and there is a refreshing frankness in covering the missteps that led up to the ridiculous dinosaurs in this story. Highly recommended.
